column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN EXERCISE, LEISURE AND SPORT
column6: Workshop in exercise, leisure and sport studies topics vary. Repeated registration permitted. Maximum 4 hours may be applied to degree.
Students will learn the proper planning process that all sport events undergo. Students will then apply these concepts in actual events that they develop and hold.

column2: MARKETING AND PROMOTIONS IN SPORT AND RECREATION
column6: Analysis of marketing from a sport and recreation manager's perspective. Emphasis on marketing strategy and tactics in sport and recreation systems. Extensive use of case studies.

This course is designed to encourage students to critically analyze how sport relates to general features of globalization and to provide insight into the connection between global and local politics (including ethnic, religious, gender, environmental and socio-spatial politics). The underlying assumption is that sport is part of a growing network of global interdependencies that bind human beings together.

Course offers an introduction to current scholarship and issues concerning sport and the media, including critical analysis of media representations with attention to gender, race, sexuality and disability; an examination of the structure of sports journalism and production and an analysis of the role of mediated sport in our culture more generally. As such the roles of institutions, producers, texts and audiences and their relationships to each other are examined.
Investigation of travel and tourism development using an interdisciplinary social science approach.

column2: PRINCIPLES AND METHODS OF COMMUNITY INCLUSION
column6: Interdisciplinary approach to the principles and methods of designing an inclusive environment. Focus is on characteristics of disability groups and societal consideration to making adaptations and accommodations. Students complete a service learning component that focuses on inclusion of people with disabilities in community life.
Analysis of leisure behavior through examination of social-psychological theories and research.

Intervention/facilitation techniques employed in therapeutic recreation practice. Integration of theory into program plans used in TR for treatment and leisure education services for people with illnesses or disabilities. .
Advanced intervention/facilitation techniques employed in therapeutic recreation practice. Professional issues related to therapeutic recreation practice.
Administrative practices of private and public leisure service agencies. Organization, philosophy, personnel and fiscal management, public relations and legal concerns will be examined.
Understanding the relationship between recreation places and the people who use them. This includes the planning, design and functioning of public and commercial recreation places.

column2: LEGAL ISSUES IN SPORT AND RECREATION
column6: Designed to alert potential recreation and sport professionals to the litigious environment prevalent in the United States and increase awareness of their legal responsibility and risk management.

column2: ETHICS IN EXERCISE, LEISURE AND SPORT
column6: Examination of selected situations in exercise, leisure and sport from an ethical reasoning perspective. A problem-oriented case study approach based upon contemporary moral issues and moral theory.
Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students. A total of 2 credits may be applied toward degree requirements.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN EXERCISE, LEISURE AND SPORT
column6: Independent study completed under the supervision of a faculty member. Written approval of supervising faculty member and school director required prior to registration. Repeatable to 6 credit hours.
Research or individual investigation. Repeated registration permitted.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN EXERCISE, LEISURE AND SPORT
column6: Selected and varied topics of relevance in exercise, leisure and sport. Registration may be repeated.
Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.
A comprehensive examination of current topics impacting administrations of professional and amateur sport programs from the local to international level.

column2: SOCIOLOGY OF SPORT AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY
column6: Sociological analysis of sport from a theoretical and empirical perspective.
A study of the pragmatic understanding necessary in the organization and management of a sports program at the high Department, college or professional level.

column2: SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY OF SPORT AND RECREATION
column6: Psychological, social and developmental factors of participation and behavior in sport exercise and recreational activities. Theoretical and applied perspectives addressed.

column2: LEGAL ISSUES IN SPORT AND RECREATION
column6: Provides students with a basic understanding of tort, contract and constitutional law in relation to sport and leisure.
Legal principles of antitrust law, injunctions, labor law and agency in sport, with a focus on professional sports.
Identification of contemporary problems and issues in collegiate sport, their history and the role of sport in colleges and universities now and in the future.
Analysis of contemporary sports promotions strategies, as well as promotion of fund raising tactics.

column2: FINANCIAL ASPECTS OF SPORT AND RECREATION
column6: Review of basic accounting, sources and uses of funds, capital budgeting, leasing and investments as they apply in a sports and recreation context. Financial software used in the sport and recreation industry will be introduced.

column4: RPTM 46000 or ELS 56000; and graduate standing.
column6: Reviews academic tourism and hospitality literature to provide students with a theoretical and empirical understanding of the tourism phenomenon. Issues include tourist motivations; the social, cultural and environmental impacts of tourism; tourism and development; and the impact of hospitality services on tourism.
Study of theoretical and applied constructs foundational to the leadership behavior applied to sport and recreation.

Develops an understanding of strategic marketing concepts and principles as they apply to the context of sport and entertainment. Examines a variety of topics related to the marketing mix, consumer/fan behavior, research methodology, as well as explore sport, entertainment and business organization relationships.
Analysis of management competencies necessary to operate sport, recreation, convocation or convention facilities. Conceptual and technical aspects of planning and design introduced.

An examination of international and intercultural changes due to travel and tourism, particularly in economic, social and environmental areas. The studies include theories and cases and form the basis upon which a sustainable tourism policy is developed. The goal of the course is to prepare students for a leadership role in tourism policy making. The course has an emphasis on reading and discussion.

column2: PHILOSOPHICAL AND SOCIAL BASES OF LEISURE AND SPORT
column6: Overview of philosophical and social foundations of leisure and sport. Contemporary theories and perspectives will be examined.

column2: CONTEMPORARY ISSUES IN LEISURE AND RECREATION
column6: Seminar to identify contemporary problems in recreation and leisure, and seek methods for their resolution.

column2: ADMINISTRATIVE PROBLEMS IN RECREATION AND LEISURE SERVICES
column6: Special problems in recreation and leisure service agencies, legal powers and liability, departmental organization, financing, personnel policies and human resource development.

column2: CONCEPTS AND TECHNIQUES IN THERAPEUTIC RECREATION
column6: Issues in the application of concepts in therapeutic recreation from a multidisciplinary perspective; study of evaluation and research.

column2: INTERNSHIP IN SPORT AND RECREATION MANAGEMENT
column6: Field experience involving supervised contact with sport and recreation administrators. Students will work as an understudy with these administrators in all phases of their positions. Repeated registration permitted.
Field experience involving supervised contact with recreation and leisure professionals. Involves experience in all phases of agency administration. Repeated registration permitted.

Supervised field experience in a sport or physical education setting. 60 hours of involvement per credit.
